options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This course is a great introduction to Interfacial Phenomena (the study of boundaries between phases, colloids, rheology, etc). 
The course builds essential engineering skills, such as mass and energy balances, and force balances. This course gives exposure to a large field within chemical engineering that I believe other courses neglect to touch upon.
In this class, I learned a lot about interfaces and some of the most important equations in this field of science. This was one of the most fun classes I have taken at Yale thus far!
This class was a great survey of interfacial phenomena - which is essentially a study of what happens at phase boundary layers.
I learned the basics for both macroscopic and microscopic interfacial phenomena. Some of the topics touched upon include pressure drops, free energy, brownian motion, and charges along a boundary.

This is a survey course on interfacial phenomena that manages to capture and integrate a broad scope of the area while giving ample opportunity for getting in the weeds of each scale and type of interfacial phenomenon.

I learned a lot about interfacial phenomena and the many aspects related to that field of science including lightly touching on rheology. Additionally, I developed skills needed in the design process for any project in the field of engineering thanks to the large design project at the end of the course.

I learned so much about interfaces, the chemistry behind them, and just generally how substances interact with each other. This can be in the form of touching, being mixed, or long ranger interactions through charge and such.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Professor Vanderlick is a key strength of this course. She is an expert in the field, and there is no one better suited to teach this course. Another strength of this course is the breadth of the content: it gives a great introduction to many different aspects of interfaces. The content is also organized in such a way that you always understand where the specifics of the material lies in the broader scope of the field. 

The only weakness of the course is the varying difficulty of the material. The course is advertised as an elective for all years (sophomores-seniors). However, the material requires a decent amount of existing knowledge (thermodynamics, fluid dynamics, etc). This makes it difficult to cater to all years, as some time is taken out of the class to devote to explaining the basics.
I think that this course was really well organized. We had weekly problem sets that coincided well with the material we were working on. There were no weaknesses that I can think of.

This class was well thought out and structured. The material from the first half of the class helped to establish the base line for the final design project. It was fun to work in groups and design a real product!

I think the strengths of this course include the fact that it's an elective without any exams and relatively fun and laid back projects where you get to work with others. Also, I enjoyed meeting with mentors a couple times through the semester to discuss our final project. I think the weaknesses of this course is that while there were answers uploaded for each hw assignment, we received no feedback on our assignments and didn't know what was being marked off. This made it hard to know what we were doing wrong.
Dr Vanderlick always has a flexible schedule for office hours and due dates which helps students immensely in juggling their semester courses. No weaknesses in the course really.

A project based course with no exams and a very clear grading system given to us in the beginning and followed through during the semester? This was an incredible class, the only weakness was that it was kind of very technical at times, mainly towards the end of the course, and while I could do the math, the concepts were extremely hard to understand. Besides that, this class was amazing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Its obviously hard to do lectures over zoom, but that is true for any class. Other than that, I think that this class was well taught.

I think that the pictures and write-ups that were much more easily accessible due to the virtual nature of the class helped with the learning. Also, I think that recording the lectures greatly helped since I could go back and watch sections I might not have understood quite as well the first time. I think sometimes the fact that some things were already written sometimes made the pace of the class too fast.
The remote learning was executed very well by Dr Vanderlick, as always.
I have no complaints about the virtual aspects of this class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It's a great survey in interfacial phenomena. Engaging lectures, thoughtful problem sets, no exams, a great project assignment (which may or may not be included in the future), and a great professor!
I would no doubt recommend this elective course to another student. The material is very interesting, and Professor Vanderlick is a great teacher.

I would highly recommend this class to any chemical engineering students (or other people interested in science). Don't be scared by the course number! This class was designed to be an approachable survey course, and Professor Vanderlick does a great job of teaching to everyone's skill levels. The content is interesting, and you learn a lot about the history of chemical engineering as well!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if they are ChemE or any other engineering. It provides you with real world skills such as working in a team and is a low stress elective.
Absolutely. Taking this course offers a whole fascinating dimension of understanding and intuition to everyday interactions in our physical environment.

I would recommend this course to any prospective chemical engineering majors who want to learn about interfacial phenomena or whoever seeks to go into the pharmaceutical industry. I believe this is a really useful elective course that will expose students to many interesting fields in which they will be able to start careers.

PLEASE TAKE THIS IF YOU NEED AN ELECTIVE FOR CHEME OR ARE JUST LOOKING FOR A STEM CLASS TO TAKE! Dr Vanderlick is an awesome, hilarious professor who clearly loves engaging with students during lecture and motivating learning. If any background knowledge is required on a certain topic that is not listed as a prerequisite for the course, Dr. V will surely cover it and provide students with the necessary material to learn effectively in the course. Awesome professor!!
Absolutely, this class was very fun and just generally a well taught and well structured class. Take it, especially if Kyle Vanderlick is teaching it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other modes of learning, although Professor Vanderlick made it really easy to meet outside of class during office hours.
Just live lectures over zoom
Live lectures are also recorded.
Remote learning
Lectures were also recorded and posted after class.
